quiz.title: AP Physics 2
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2, Quiz 4: Gas Laws & Thermodynamic Processes
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Ideal gas law, kinetic theory, isobaric/isochoric processes, heat calculations, pressure-volume relationships, work calculations

questions.question: One mole of an ideal gas has a temperature of 100°C. If this gas fills the 10.0 m³ volume of a closed container, what is the pressure of the gas?
options: 310 Pa

questions.question: An ideal gas is enclosed in a container. The volume of the container is reduced to half the original volume at constant temperature. According to kinetic theory, what is the best explanation for the increase in pressure created by the gas?
options: The average speed of the gas particles decreases, but they hit the container walls more frequently.
The average speed of the gas particles is unchanged, but they hit the container walls more frequently.
The average speed of the gas particles increases as does the frequency with which they hit the container walls.
The average speed of the gas particles increases, overcoming the decreased frequency that they hit the container walls.
questions.explanation: Constant temperature means average kinetic energy and rms speed are unchanged. Halving volume doubles the number density of molecules, so collision frequency with walls doubles, increasing pressure.

questions.question: A mole of a monatomic ideal gas has pressure P, volume V, and temperature T. Which of the following processes would result in the greatest amount of energy added to the gas from heat?
options: A process doubling the temperature at constant pressure.
An adiabatic expansion doubling the volume.
A process doubling the pressure at constant volume.
A process doubling the volume at constant temperature.
questions.explanation: For monatomic gas: \( C_P = \frac{5}{2}R \), \( C_V = \frac{3}{2}R \). (A) \( Q = C_P \Delta T = \frac{5}{2}R T \). (B) Adiabatic: Q = 0. (C) \( Q = C_V \Delta T = \frac{3}{2}R T \). (D) Isothermal: \( Q = W = RT \ln 2 \approx 0.693RT \). Largest is \( \frac{5}{2}RT \).

questions.question: An ideal gas in a closed container of volume 6.0 L is at a temperature of 100ºC. If the pressure of the gas is 2.5 atm, how many moles of gas are in the container?
An ideal gas undergoes an isobaric expansion followed by an isochoric cooling. Which of the following statements must be true after the completion of these processes?
options: The final pressure is less than the original pressure.
The final volume is less than the original volume.
The final temperature is less than the original temperature.
The total quantity of heat, Q, associated with these processes is positive.
questions.explanation: Isobaric expansion: pressure constant, volume increases, temperature increases. Isochoric cooling: volume constant (now larger than original), pressure decreases with temperature. Final pressure < initial pressure. Other statements are not necessarily true.

questions.question: Two moles of a monatomic ideal gas undergoes the process from A to B, shown in the diagram above by the solid line. Using the sign convention that work is positive when surroundings do work on the system, how much work is done in the process AB?
questions.explanation: Process AB is isobaric (constant pressure) expansion. Work done on gas: \( W = -P\Delta V = -nR\Delta T \). With \( n = 2 \) mol, \( R = 8.314 \) J/mol·K, \( \Delta T = 600 - 300 = 300 \) K, \( W = -2 \times 8.314 \times 300 \approx -5000 \) J. Negative sign means gas does work on surroundings.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery: You understand ideal gas law calculations, kinetic theory explanations, heat calculations for different processes, sequential thermodynamic process analysis, and work calculations with sign conventions.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp: Review PV=nRT, kinetic theory principles, heat capacities for monatomic gases, behavior of isobaric/isochoric processes, and work = -PΔV for isobaric cases.
scoreMessages.50: Needs review: Focus on ideal gas law applications, constant T vs constant P/V processes, heat calculation formulas, process sequences, and work sign conventions.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: PV = nRT, constant T: P ∝ 1/V, kinetic theory: T ∝ average KE, Q = nCΔT for constant P/V, isobaric = constant P, work on gas = -PΔV for expansion.
